entry.title: UNMASKING THE GUNMEN Police: Kenya attacker was son of government official

entry.title: Jury selection to begin for Oklahoma man accused of abuse
entry.summary:
OKLAHOMA CITY (AP) - Jury selection is scheduled to begin in the federal trial of an Oklahoma man accused of sexual misconduct with children at an orphanage in Kenya.

Matthew Lane Durham was a volunteer at the Upendo Children's Home in Nairobi, Kenya.

entry.title: Kenya fight against Shebab shifts to its own backyard
entry.summary: From hit and run attacks and massacres to a shopping trip, Somali-led Shebab militants are on the march in northeastern Kenya.

entry.title: South Sudanese dissident politicians return home from Kenya, raising hope for peace
entry.summary: Under the mediation of a regional bloc, some of the dissidents were later released and sent to Kenya.

entry.title: Kenya police clash with Shebab in Garissa
entry.summary:
Kenya media and local officials initially said that between 10 and 20 police were killed, while a police spokesman said 13 officers were missing.

It remains unclear if the latest string of attacks have been carried out by Shebab units based in Somalia, or the group's cells inside Kenya -- where the militants have stepped up recruitment and operations.

entry.title: Kenyan police officers killed in attack claimed by Al-Shabab
entry.summary:
Kenya's Daily Nation newspaper reported that at least 20 police officers were feared dead in the attack in Yumbis village.

Kenya's interior ministry said Friday it had "thwarted an attempted attack" on Thursday evening after Yumbis residents spotted armed militants in the area and alerted the authorities.

entry.title: World Briefing: Kenya: Thousands Attend Italian Nun?s Beatification
entry.summary: Sister Stefani, who belonged to the Consolata Missionary Sisters, arrived in Kenya in 1915, according to a website dedicated to her beatification.

entry.title: Al Shabaab attacks village in Kenya's Garissa
entry.summary:
The Somalia-based al Shabaab group, which has carried out frequent attacks in Kenya in recent years to try to force Nairobi to pull its troops out of Somalia, struck a university in the same area last month, killing 148 people.

Kenya's tourism industry, a top foreign exchange earner, has borne the brunt of the attacks, as worried tourists cancel their bookings.

entry.title: Oldest known stone tools found in Kenya
entry.summary:
New York: By taking a wrong turn in a dry riverbed in Kenya, scientists discovered a trove of stone tools far older than any ever found before.

The Nature paper describes 149 stones and stone flakes found west of Lake Turkana in a remote area of northern Kenya.

entry.title: Oldest known stone tools found in Kenya
entry.summary: Sonia Harmand and Jason Lewis with stone tools found in the West Turkana area of Kenya.

entry.title: Oldest Known Stone Tools Discovered in Kenya
Kenya asks Burundi president to postpone election
entry.summary:
Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta has told Burundi leader Pierre Nkurunziza that he should postpone a presidential election due next month after last week's failed military coup, Kenyatta's spokesman said on Monday.

Regional leaders want the election date changed from June 26 to create a "conducive environment" but the vote should still be held within the current electoral cycle, which comes to an end in late August, Kenya's Esipisu said.

entry.title: Kenya's Kenyatta asks Burundian president to postpone poll

entry.title: Kenya Red Cross: 54 Killed in Cattle Raid Attacks
entry.summary: Kenya's interior minister said Wednesday he is deeply disappointed over the killings that happened even after regional politicians signed a peace accord in January.

entry.title: Kenya Red Cross: 54 Killed in Cattle Raid Attacks
entry.summary: Livestock-keeping nomadic tribes in Kenya's north routinely engage in the traditional practice of cattle raids which experts say has become more deadly because the tribes have moved from using spear and arrows to guns.

entry.title: Kenya Red Cross: 54 killed in cattle raid attacks
Suspected cattle rustlers kill 45 in northwest Kenya: administrator
entry.summary:
ISIOLO, Kenya (Reuters) - Suspected cattle rustlers ambushed and killed at least 45 people in a village in northwest Kenya, then drove away hundreds of livestock, a regional administrator said.

At least 14 people also died in a fight between two pastoralist communities on Monday, on the borders of Kenya's northern Samburu and Marsabit counties, the regional manager for the Kenya Red Cross, Mugambi Gitonga, said.

entry.title: US gives $45 million to help Kenya with refugee crisis
entry.summary:
He said he came away from the discussions with a deeper appreciation for the refugee burden Kenya carries.

The U.S. has provided Kenya hundreds of millions of dollars in counterterrorism and refugee assistance in recent years.

entry.title: US gives $45 million to help Kenya with refugee crisis
entry.summary:
U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry helps feed a baby elephant while touring the Sheldrick Center Elephant Orphanage at the Nairobi National Park, Sunday, May 3, 2015, in Nairobi, Kenya.

Earlier Monday, Kerry laid a wreath for the victims of the deadly 1998 bombing of the U.S. Embassy in Kenya.

entry.title: US gives $45 million to help Kenya with refugee crisis
entry.summary:
Secretary of State John Kerry meets with Kenyan Chief Justice Willy Mutunga at the Nairobi Serena Hotel, Monday, May 4, 2015, in Nairobi, Kenya.

Kenya's burden is only a piece of a larger refugee challenge that has grown more acute with fighting in South Sudan - whose leaders Kerry publicly lambasted Monday - and more recently across the Gulf of Aden in Yemen.

entry.title: US Gives $45 Million to Help Kenya With Refugee Crisis
entry.summary: Kerry said he received assurances Monday from Kenya's once-shunned president, Uhuru Kenyatta, that the camp would stay open while an international plan is devised to make Somalia safe enough for its citizens to return.

entry.title: US gives $45 million to help Kenya with refugee crisis
"No room" for gays in Kenya, says deputy president
entry.summary: "The Republic of Kenya is a republic that worships God. We have no room for gays and those others," Ruto told a Nairobi church congregation in the national Swahili language, according to an online video posted by Kenyan broadcaster KTN.

entry.title: 'No room' for gays in Kenya, says deputy president
entry.summary:
NAIROBI - Kenya's deputy president has said there is "no room" for homosexuality in Kenyan society, the latest comments from an African government to anger activists and likely also to annoy Western donors who say gays are targetted on the continent.

"Kenya's deputy president joins an important tradition by Africans in power to spread hate in church on a Sunday," Binyavanga Wainana, a prominent Kenyan writer who is openly gay, said on his Twitter account.

Last week, Kenya's High Court ruled that a prominent gay rights group could register as a non-governmental organisation after a board overseeing such applications refused its request.

entry.title: Kerry due in Kenya after years of estrangement
entry.summary:
US Secretary of State John Kerry arrives in Kenya on Sunday for talks on security cooperation and ahead of US President Barack Obama's visit to his late father's home country.

The ICC has since abandoned the case against Kenyatta over his role in the 2007-2008 post-election violence, citing a lack of evidence and Kenya's failure to cooperate -- somewhat removing Kenyatta's pariah status.

"It's about reinforcing and deepening the relationship that we have had with Kenya, and it's also partially in preparation for President Obama's trip that's going to take place at the end of July."

entry.title: Kerry in Kenya to offer help against militants-officials
entry.summary: Assistance should also help poor communities in Kenya that al Shabaab may seek to win over, he said.

entry.title: Kerry in Kenya to offer help against militants: officials
entry.summary:
U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry departs for Kenya in Colombo, Sri Lanka May 3, 2015.

NAIROBI (Reuters) - U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Kenya on Sunday to offer help in countering Somali al Shabaab militants who have staged deadly attacks there and elsewhere in East Africa.

Kerry will also address Kenya's human rights in meetings with President Uhuru Kenyatta and other government officials as well as discussing the troubled peace process in South Sudan and violence in Burundi, a U.S. official said.

entry.title: Kenya's Kandie wins Prague international marathon
entry.summary: Felix Kipchirchir Kandie of Kenya won the Prague International Marathon on Sunday while Yebrgual Melese of Ethiopia claimed the women's race.

entry.title: Garissa attack: Kenyan minister admits tipoff on al-Shabaab assault was ignored
entry.summary: Kenya's interior minister has admitted that intelligence was ignored and the security response botched regarding the Islamist massacre of nearly 150 people at Garissa university in April.

entry.title: 'Black-ish' creator Kenya Barris set to write 'Good Times' movie for Sony
entry.summary: "Black-ish" creator Kenya Barris has been set to write the screenplay for a "Good Times" film based on the hit '70s sitcom, his manager confirmed to The Associated Press.

entry.title: Kenya: Court orders government to register gay rights group
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - A Kenyan court has ordered a government agency that regulates non-governmental organizations to recognize and register a human rights group seeking to protect the rights of gay people in the country.

entry.title: Thailand Seizes 3 Tons of Elephant Tusks Smuggled From Kenya
entry.summary:
Thailand seized 3 tons of ivory hidden in tea leaf sacks from Kenya in the second-biggest bust in the country's history, one week after the biggest seizure, customs officials said Monday.

The ivory, hidden among tea leaves, was shipped out of Kenya on March 24 and went through ports in Sri Lanka, Malaysia and Singapore before coming to Thailand, he said.

entry.title: Thailand Seizes 3 Tons of Elephant Tusks Smuggled From Kenya
entry.summary: He said Monday that the ivory was shipped out of Kenya last month and arrived at the Thai port on Saturday.

entry.title: Kenya: 9 security chiefs suspended over al-Shabab attack
U.N. refugee chief to visit Kenya to plan return of Somali refugees
entry.summary:
UNHCR has urged Kenya to rethink its plan, warning that it is illegal under the 1951 U.N. Refugee Convention to force refugees back to areas where their lives are threatened.

UNHCR, Kenya and Somalia will ensure that returning refugees have access to healthcare, education and jobs, he added.

Kenya hosts the second largest number of refugees in Africa after Ethiopia.

entry.title: Ethiopia?s Desisa, Kenya?s Rotich winners at Boston Marathon

entry.title: Kenya official: I did not cause delay in ending attack

entry.title: Microgrids and mobile tech bring solar power to rural Kenya
entry.summary:
Tapping into Kenya's abundance of sunshine, the company has installed high-capacity solar panels at power hubs, where energy is stored in high-voltage batteries.

To help get power to those who have never had it before, SteamaCo is utilizing Kenya's reputation as a nation that lives and works by mobile phone.

By tapping into Kenya's fast-evolving mobile culture, the company can also instantly communicate with its customers, sending text reminders when users' accounts are running low so they can top up.

entry.title: UN urges Kenya to reconsider demand to shut refugee camp
entry.summary: Kenyan Deputy President William Ruto made the demand Saturday, urging the agency to send the more than 400,000 refugees living at the Dadaab camp back home or see Kenya relocate them itself.

entry.title: Athletics Kenya bans agents of Dennis Kimetto pending doping investigations
entry.summary:
Kenya's athletics federation has suspended the agents of marathon world record holder Dennis Kimetto and other top stars while it investigates the spike in doping among the country's runners.

Kiplagat also said he would be stepping aside from his post at Athletic Kenya from 1 May to campaign for a seat in the IAAF.

entry.title: Kenya 'grass cutter' gang rapists jailed for 15 years
entry.summary: "While Kenya boasts one of the most progressive legal and policy frameworks for addressing sexual violence, Liz's case and countless others have revealed significant failures of local authorities to adequately address sexual violence."

entry.title: Punishment for Kenyan gang rapists lifted from cutting grass to 15 years' jail
entry.summary:
The then 16-year-old victim, known by the pseudonym Liz, was reportedly attacked, beaten and then raped by six men as she returned from her grandfather's funeral in western Kenya in June, 2013.

Rape is a serious problem in Kenya but is seldom taken seriously by the police, rights groups say.

entry.title: Kenya asks the UN to shut down refugee camp for Somalis

Somali refugees in Kenya number around 450,000, most of them at Dadaab, the world's largest refugee camp, the UNHCR said.

entry.title: Kenyan official: 1 student killed, 141 hurt after explosion
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - One Kenyan student was killed and 141 injured in a stampede Sunday on the campus of the University of Nairobi when students mistook several accidental explosions for an extremist attack, according to an official.

entry.title: Kenya demands UN move massive Dadaab refugee camp across border to Somalia
entry.summary:
Kenya has given the United Nations three months to remove a camp housing more than half a million Somali refugees, as part of a get-tough response to the killing of 148 people by Somali gunmen at a Kenyan university.

Dadaab hosts more than 600,000 thousand Somali refugees, according to Ruto, in a remote, dry corner in northeast Kenya.

"The way America changed after 9/11 is the way Kenya will change after Garissa," he said, referring to the university that was attacked on April 2.

entry.title: Kenya: Hero's burial for officer who helped stop attack
entry.summary: Thousands have gathered in a remote village in Kenya's Rift Valley to give a hero's burial to a police officer who died fighting to end an Islamic extremist attack on a university which killed 148 people.

entry.title: Kenya: Hero's burial for officer who helped stop attack

entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - There was sobbing and silent grief.

entry.title: After attack and backlash, Kenya faces battle to win over Muslims
entry.summary:
Without the cooperation of local people like Bare, experts say Kenya will struggle to glean vital on-the-ground intelligence to stop crude but highly lethal assaults by Somalia's al Shabaab militants.

Winning favour with Muslim communities near Somalia has been made more urgent by al Shabaab's switch in tactics to target Kenya's frontier regions near the porous 700km border.

Kenyan Defence Forces (KDF) spokesman David Obonyo denied the troops had a track record of brutality against Muslims, who make up about 10 percent of Kenya's 44 million people.

Mass security sweeps also breed radicalisation and help al Shabaab portray itself as the protector of Muslims in Kenya, Muslim groups say.

entry.title: Unsung heroes: Kenya counselors help relatives of the dead
entry.summary: "You have to be there," whether it means embracing a grieving parent, talking or just being present without saying anything, said Sammy Mwangi, a worker with the Kenya Red Cross.

entry.title: Community radio brings forecasts to Kenya?s most climate vulnerable
entry.summary:
Nganyi RANET - it stands for "Radio Internet" - is a community radio station set up by the Kenya Meteorological Service to target communities particularly vulnerable to climate extremes.

There are now five RANET radio stations in Kenya where the climate change impacts are particularly strong.

entry.title: Kenya freezes key money transfers to Somalia after university terror attack
Kenya freezes key money transfers to Somalia after university terror attack
entry.summary:
Kenya has frozen key money transfer companies vital for Somalia after the police chief issued a list of 85 people and businesses with suspected links to the Al-Qaeda-linked group al-Shabab.

Their suspension in Kenya would have major impact on money transfers, with aid agencies warning in the past their suspension would hit some of poorest people the hardest.

entry.title: Kenya police: 1 gunman identified in attack that killed 148
After Islamist attack, armed guards shield Kenyan churches
entry.summary: GARISSA, Kenya (Reuters) - Kenyan churches used armed guards to protect their Easter congregations on Sunday, days after gunmen from the Islamist al Shabaab group killed nearly 150 people at a Kenyan university.

entry.title: Reeling from attack, Christians attend emotional Easter services at church in Garissa, Kenya
Prayers, fear mark Easter services in Garissa, Kenya
Militant group al-Shabab threatens more attacks on Kenya
Kenyatta says campus attackers 'embedded' in Kenya's Muslim community
entry.summary: In a message directed at Kenyans, the al Qaeda aligned group said the raid on Garissa was revenge for Kenya's military presence in Somalia and mistreatment of Muslims within Kenya.

entry.title: Kenyatta says campus attackers 'embedded' in Kenya's Muslim community
Three days of mourning as Kenya grapples with Garissa massacre
entry.summary: Kenyatta's comments will put more pressure on Kenya's Muslim community, who make up about 10 percent of the 44-million-strong population.

entry.title: Kenyatta says Garissa attackers 'embedded' in Kenya Muslim community
entry.summary:
Four attackers died at Garissa, but Kenya has not named them or announced their nationalities.

The attack at Garissa, which lies 120 miles from the Somali border, has put Kenya on high alert and spooked its Christian communities after reports the gunmen sought out Christian students while sparing some Muslims.

entry.title: Three days of mourning as Kenya grapples with Garissa massacre
entry.summary:
Along Kenya's palm-fringed coastline, where several resort towns cater mainly for Western tourists, police have deployed armed officers in major public buildings.

"Officers are everywhere both on the ground and in the air. We have two helicopters that will be patrolling the entire coastal area," Robert Kitur, police chief for Kenya's Indian Ocean coast region, told Reuters.

Garissa Governor Nathif Jama said the region has a number of security "soft spots", including schools and hospitals, and asked for more boots on the ground in his county, which forms part of Kenya's porous 700km border with Somalia.

entry.title: Kenya?s revenge: Naked corpses paraded
entry.summary: POLICE have paraded the naked corpses of Somali al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabab gunmen who slaughtered almost 150 people in one of Kenya's worst massacres, hours after the militants threatened "another bloodbath".

entry.title: Kenya: Extremists vow more attacks; president responds
entry.summary: Women look across as Kenya Defence Forces (KDF) soldiers arrive at a hospital to escort the bodies of the attackers to be put on public view, in Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya: Extremists vow more attacks; president responds
entry.summary: A woman covers her mouth after going in to view the bodies of the alleged attackers, having been encouraged to do so by security guards, at the hospital mortuary in Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya: Extremists vows more attacks; president responds
entry.summary: Women in the crowd cover their faces to protect against the smell as authorities display the bodies of the alleged attackers before about 2,000 people in a large open area in central Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya Survivor Found in School After Attack Killed 148
entry.summary: Survivor of the killings at Garissa University College Cynthia Cheroitich, 19, who was found on Saturday two days after the attack, drinks some milk in a hospital ward in Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya: Survivor found in school attack which killed 148
entry.summary: Women go through the local papers of the news on Thursday's attack on a university, at Chiromo funeral home, Nairobi, Kenya, Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Kenyan cities 'will run red with blood,' al-Shabaab vows
entry.summary: The Kenya Red Cross said it had found a woman survivor on Saturday in the university, two days after the siege ended.

entry.title: Somali militants vow to turn Kenyan cities 'red with blood'
entry.summary: Along Kenya's palm-fringed coastline, police have put armed officers in major public buildings.

entry.title: Somali militants threaten more attacks against Kenya
entry.summary: The al Qaeda aligned group said the attack was retribution for Kenya's presence in Somalia and mistreatment of Muslims within Kenya.

entry.title: Somali militants threaten more bloody attacks against Kenya
entry.summary:
MOGADISHU (Reuters) - Somali militants on Saturday threatened to stage more bloody attacks on Kenya after the group's fighters killed nearly 150 people during an assault on a Kenyan university on Thursday.

In the message, directed at the Kenyan public, the group vowed a long and gruesome war, saying Kenya's cities will "run red with blood".

entry.title: Pope decries persecution of Christians, including in Kenya
entry.summary: Pope Francis prays for persecuted Christians as Easter celebrations begin after Islamist militants killed at least 147 people in Kenya.

entry.title: Pope decries persecution of Christians, including in Kenya
entry.summary: Rome: Pope Francis presided at two Good Friday services, praying for persecuted Christians a day after Islamist militants attacked a university in Kenya, killing at least 147 people.

entry.title: Barack Obama vows to stand 'hand in hand' with Kenya after massacre
entry.summary: "The future of Kenya will not be defined by violence and terror; it will be shaped by young people like those at Garissa University College," he added.

entry.title: Kenya mourns 148 dead in university attack by militants
entry.summary:
A woman gestures after she viewed the body of a relative killed in Thursday's attack on a university, at Chiromo funeral home, Nairobi, Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

Kenyan Muslims demonstrate against Thursday's attack and in solidarity with non-Muslims who were targeted, on a street in Garissa, Kenya Friday, April 3, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya mourns 148 dead in university attack by militants
entry.summary: Survivors and relatives gave other harrowing accounts of the siege by Islamic extremists as Kenya on Friday mourned the victims of the attack, the deadliest since the 1998 bombing of the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi that killed more than 200 people.

entry.title: Kenya massacre victims were lined up and shot as they phoned parents
entry.summary:
The gunmen, from the Somali Islamist terrorist group al-Shabaab, stormed Garissa University in north-east Kenya.

Maureen Manyengo, a 21-year-old Christian from western Kenya, who was training to be a teacher, described how she hid inside her wardrobe after seeing several friends killed.

So far, 147 people have been confirmed dead and 79 injured in Kenya's worst terrorist attack in two decades, but officials have admitted that the number killed could rise as piles of bodies are recounted.

Joseph Nkaissery, Kenya's interior minister, confirmed that the gunmen had been strapped with explosives and blew up "like bombs" as they were shot by a special forces squad.

entry.title: Kenya massacre victims were lined up and shot as they phoned parents
entry.summary: Peter Aling'o, senior researcher with the Institute for Security Studies in Nairobi, said al-Shabaab was taking advantage of "gaps" in Kenya's intelligence-led security planning.

entry.title: Shock, defiance in Kenya after Shebab massacre 148 at university
entry.summary: The day-long siege of Garissa University in which 148 people, mostly students, were killed was Kenya's deadliest attack since the 1998 bombing of the US embassy in Nairobi, and the bloodiest ever by the Al-Qaeda-affiliated militants.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus
entry.summary:
Members of Kenya Defense Forces secure the area of the Garissa University College in Garissa, northeastern Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

A victim of Thursday's university attack is assisted to a plane by medical staff prior to being airlifted to Nairobi, at the Garissa military airstrip, Garissa, Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus
entry.summary: The attack at Garissa University College happened six days after Britain advised "against all but essential travel" to parts of Kenya, including Garissa.

entry.title: Horror in Kenya: Somali militants massacre students
entry.summary: Medics help an injured person at Kenyatta national Hospital in Nairobi, Kenya, after an attack by gunmen at Garissa University College.

entry.title: Pope condemns Kenya school attack as 'senseless brutality'
Survivor of Deadly Kenya University Attack Says Gunmen Had Scouted Campus
entry.summary: In Nairobi, Kenya's capital, family members were lining up at a morgue where about 20 bodies had already been airlifted from Garissa, victims of the worst attack in Kenya since the 1998 bombing of the U.S. Embassy by al-Qaida which killed more than 200 people.

entry.title: Al-Shabaab gunmen targeted Christian prayer site in Kenya attack, survivor says
entry.summary: The al-Qaida-linked group has been blamed for a series of attacks in Kenya, including the siege at the Westgate Mall in Nairobi in 2013 that killed 67 people, as well as other violence in the north.

entry.title: Kenya college attack survivor hid among dead
entry.summary: In Nairobi, Kenya's capital, family members were lining up at a morgue where about 20 bodies had already been airlifted from Garissa.

entry.title: Kenya college attack survivor hid among dead
entry.summary: GARISSA, Kenya - The militants who slaughtered 147 people in a Kenyan school appeared to have planned extensively, even targeting a site where Christians had gone to pray, a survivor said Friday.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus
entry.summary:
Somali President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud called for stronger collaboration between his country and Kenya to defeat al-Shabab.

Odula reported from Nairobi, Kenya.

entry.title: Al-Shabab militants kill 147 at university in Kenya
entry.summary: Police identified a possible mastermind of the attack as Mohammed Mohamud, who is alleged to lead al-Shabab's cross-border raids into Kenya, and they posted a $220,000 bounty for him.

entry.title: Kenya disaster operations center, interior minister: 147 fatalities in attack on college.
entry.summary: Kenya disaster operations center, interior minister: 147 fatalities in attack on college.

entry.title: 147 dead as al-Shabab gunmen attack Garissa University: Kenya interior minister
entry.summary: Kenya's president says hostages have been taken in the attack on a college in the northeastern town of Garissa.

entry.title: The Latest: Officials: 147 die in Kenya attack
entry.summary: They believe he is the mastermind of the attack on a college in Garissa, in northeast Kenya.

entry.title: Gunmen storm university in Kenya killing 70
entry.summary: Al-Shabab gunmen stormed a university in northeastern Kenya at dawn, killing more than 70 people in the group's bloodiest attack in the East African country, officials said.

entry.title: The Latest: Death toll more than 70 in Kenya college attack
Over 70 dead as masked gunmen attack Garissa University: Kenya interior minister
entry.summary: Also known by the names Dulyadin and Gamadhere, he was a teacher at an Islamic religious school, or madrassa, and claimed responsibility for a bus attack in Makka, Kenya, in November that killed 28 people.

entry.title: Al-Shabaab Kenya attack: death toll rises to 70 - live updates
entry.summary:
Kenyan Interior Minister Joseph Nkaissery says that more than 70 people have been killed in an attack by Somali-based Islamic extremists on a college in northeast Kenya.

From Kenya's interior ministry.

entry.title: Gunmen attack university in northeastern Kenya
entry.summary:
Kenyan police officers take cover outside the Garissa University College during an attack by gunmen in Garissa, Kenya, Thursday, April 2, 2015.

Some students without their shirts of the Garissa University College get out of a house where they seek refuge after escaping from an attack by gunmen in Garissa, Kenya, Thursday, April 2, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya says 29 people wounded in attack on university, most with gunshot wounds
Masked gunmen storm university in Kenya
entry.summary:
Police and military surrounded the buildings and were trying to secure the area in eastern Kenya, police officer Musa Yego said.

Kenya's National Police Service said in a written statement that armed attackers forced their way onto the campus by shooting at guards, triggering a "fierce shootout" with police guarding student hostels.

entry.title: Police: Gunmen attack university in eastern Kenya, killing 2
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Gunmen attacked Garissa University College early Thursday, shooting indiscriminately in campus hostels, killing at least two people and wounding four others, police said.

entry.title: Masked gunmen storm Kenya university
entry.summary: Heavy gunfire and explosions were heard and the stand-off was ongoing at the Garissa University College, in Kenya.

entry.title: Masked gunmen storm Kenya university
entry.summary: Al-Qaeda linked al-Shabaab has vowed to punish Kenya for sending troops into Somalia alongside African Union peacekeepers to fight the group.

entry.title: Masked gunmen storm Kenya college campus, local media says
entry.summary: Somali Islamist militant group al-Shabaab has carried out several attacks in Garissa and across Kenya in the past, including the 2013 attack on an upscale shopping mall in the capital Nairobi.

entry.title: Police: Gunmen attack university in eastern Kenya
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - A police official says masked gunmen have stormed a university campus in Garissa Town in eastern Kenya.

entry.title: Masked Gunmen Attack University In Kenya
entry.summary: Kenya's northern and eastern regions, which border Somalia, have been most affected by attacks blamed on al Shabaab Islamists from Somalia.

entry.title: Police: Masked gunmen attack university in Kenya
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Police: Heavy gunfire reported as masked gunmen attack Garrisa university in Kenya's northeast.

entry.title: Obama to make presidential trip to father's homeland Kenya
entry.summary: Barack Obama will make a long-awaited trip to Kenya later this year, visiting his father's homeland for the first time since becoming US president six years ago, the White House said Monday.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
entry.summary: The elder Obama died more than 30 years ago, though the president has other family still living in Kenya.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
entry.summary: During a trip to other African countries last year, he said he was likely to visit Kenya before leaving the White House.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
entry.summary: The White House says Obama will visit Kenya in July for the Global Entrepreneurship Summit, which brings together business leaders, international organizations and governments.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
entry.summary:
WASHINGTON (AP) - President Barack Obama will make his first trip as president to Kenya, the country of his father's birth.

Obama visited Kenya as a U.S. senator, but never as president.

The president's father came to the United States from Kenya for school and returned to his home country after his son's birth.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
Kenya's president apologizes for government's past wrongs
entry.summary: The government-funded report found that Kenya's second and third presidents, Daniel Arap Moi and Mwai Kibaki, headed governments that were responsible for massacres, economic crimes and grand corruption, among other violations.

entry.title: Kenya's president apologizes for government's past wrongs
entry.summary: Kenya's state security agencies, particularly the police and army, have been the main perpetrators of human rights violations, including massacres, enforced disappearances, torture and sexual violence, the report said.

entry.title: Kenya's president apologizes for past wrongs by his government and previous regimes
entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya - Kenya's president has apologized to the Kenyan people for past wrongs committed both by his government and past regimes.

Kenya's Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission report had recommended that the president apologize to the public.

The report names the president and his deputy as being among those suspected of planning and financing Kenya's 2007-08 postelection violence in which more than 1,000 people died.

entry.title: 'No blacks' Chinese restaurant shut down in Kenya
entry.summary: Reports said the restaurant's Chinese owners and managers had also been summoned by Kenya's immigration authorities.

entry.title: British Islamist in Kenya 'possessed bomb-making materials'
entry.summary: Materials recovered from the home of a British terrorism suspect in Kenya were capable of making explosives, a court in Mombasa heard Friday.

entry.title: Al-Shabab claim responsibility for 4 dead in Kenya
entry.summary:
"The attack is part of a series of attacks targeting the Northern Frontier District region under Kenya's occupation," said al-Shabab's radio Andulus."The Mujahideen forces who carried out the attack safely returned to base."

Kenya's northern and eastern region border Somalia and a significant number of inhabitants there are Kenyan-Somalis.

Police statistics show that 312 people have been killed in al-Shabab attacks in Kenya from 2012 to 2014.

entry.title: Al-Shabab claim attack which killed 4 people, wounded 3 northern Kenya
entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya - Somalia's al-Shabab Islamic extremists claimed responsibility Wednesday for an attack that killed four people in Kenya's volatile northern region, bringing to 12 the number of those killed by the militants since Friday.

Al-Shabab has been attacking Kenya since Kenyan troops were deployed to Somalia in Oct 2011 to fight the militants.

entry.title: New Shebab attack in northeast Kenya kills four
entry.summary:
Four people died in a gun and grenade attack on Wajir town in northeast Kenya, the latest in a series of cross-border raids by Somalia's Shebab militants, officials said Wednesday.

The attack is the fourth in five days in Kenya's remote and increasingly lawless northeast, which borders war-torn Somalia.

entry.title: Islamic extremist group al-Shabab suspected in northern Kenya attack that kills 1, wounds 3
entry.summary: Adan Duale, a Kenyan Somali who is majority leader in parliament, was quoted on the BBC Somali Service on Saturday telling al-Shabab to leave Kenya alone.

entry.title: Al-Shabab suspected in Kenya attack that kills 1, wounds 3
entry.summary:
"If you wish to, we shall send you elders, religious leaders and politicians. We shall come, tell us your whereabouts. Leave Kenya alone," Duale said in a statement that many in Kenya interpreted as a call for negotiations with al-Shabab.

But Duale said Sunday on his Twitter account that Kenya will never negotiate with "terrorists."

Kenya has experienced a string of attacks since it sent troops into Somalia in October 2011.

entry.title: Kenya Police: 3 people killed in attack on governors convoy
entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) " Islamic militants attacked a governor's convoy in north Kenya on Friday for the second time in five months, killing three people, a police official said.

Al-Shabab, an Islamic extremist group, has vowed to inflict violent attacks on Kenya because it has contributed troops to the African Union force supporting the western-backed government in Somalia.

Hundreds of teachers in parts of northern Kenya that borders Somalia have refused to return to work, fearing attacks by the Islamic extremists despite government reassurance of increased security.

entry.title: Kenya: Businessmen, ex-officials charged for fraud and abuse of office
entry.summary: Al-Shabab extremists from Somalia have carried out 129 attacks in Kenya since Oct. 2011 saying its retribution for the Kenyan troop presence in Somalia.

entry.title: Kenya burns 15 tonnes of ivory to deter elephant poachers
entry.summary:
A Kenya Wildlife Services officer stands near a burning pile of 15 tonnes of elephant ivory seized in Kenya.

Nairobi:Kenya has burned 15 tonnes of elephant tusks and rhino horns as part of efforts to curb poaching of the mammals in the East African country.

entry.title: Kenya burns 15 tonnes of ivory to deter elephant poachers
entry.summary: A Kenya Wildlife Service officer next to the pile of contraband ivory.

entry.title: Kenya burns 15 tonnes of ivory in anti-poaching fight
entry.summary:
NAIROBI - Kenya burnt 15 tonnes of ivory on Tuesday and promised to destroy all of its stockpile this year, the latest step in its campaign against elephant poaching.

"As part of Kenya's continued policy to put ivory beyond economic use ... I will today burn 15 tonnes of ivory at this historic site in Nairobi National Park," President Uhuru Kenyatta said during a ceremony at the park.

entry.title: Kenya destroy 15 tons of ivory taken from poachers
entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Kenya's president set fire to 15 tons of elephant tusks during World Wildlife Day Tuesday to discourage poaching and trade in ivory.

Hamilton said Kenya has a long way to go before it can be clear of the poaching menace.

"We would like to tell the world to stop the trade in ivory because it is destroying our economy, our heritage, our environment," said Paul Udoto, a spokesman for the Kenya Wildlife Service.

entry.title: Kenya destroy 15 tons of ivory taken from poachers
entry.summary:
A firefighter controls the flames as 15 tons of elephant tusks are set on fire during an anti-poaching ceremony at Nairobi National Park in Nairobi, Kenya Tuesday, March 3, 2015.

The years 2011, 2012 and 2013 witnessed the highest levels of poaching since a poaching crisis in the 1980s, Kenya's Wildlife Service has said.
